results.title: Science fiction: Jules Verne to Ray Bradbury... and beyond
results.creator_credit: Barbara Winard and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: The three parts of these videos give a brief overview of science fiction through history. Clips from films and television programs are used as illustrations. “From Lucian to Jules Verne” traces the beginnings of science fiction in social satire and criticism with the works of Lucian, Thomas More and Swift until Jules Verne revived the genre by tapping into scientific possibilities. “From H. G. Wells to George Orwell” shows how H. G. Wells linked the old and the new science fiction writers, who developed the space opera, magazines, and the science fiction film, culminating in Orwell’s grim visions of the future. “From Isaac Asimov to Arthur C. Clarke” documents the influences of outside factors such as World War II, the cold war, Vietnam and the hippy experience of the 60’s in the works of Asimov, Heinlein, Herbert and Clarke. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.

results.title: Scottsman drops his turkey
results.brief_description: We’re on the slippery slope towards Christmas, that hectic time of year when we rush around desperately trying to get everything done. Come Christmas dinner we can relax a bit, the work is done and we get to enjoy the fruits of our labours, unless you’re this guy…
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

results.title: Science and money
results.creator_credit: Mike Milne, Michael Coyle and BBC
results.brief_description: While this program is about British coinage, the information on coin alloys and the reasoning for notes versus coins remains relevant. Shows coins actually being tested from the basic alloy through the entire production process.

results.title: Scott no friends
results.brief_description:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. His 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised at home and abroad for lacking any real details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day, and the French president labelled him a liar over the submarine fiasco. Other world leaders made their displeasure to the government’s handling of recent issues known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. Not only did the French president label him a liar over the submarine fiasco, his 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised around the world (and at home) for lacking any new funding, policies or details – except faith that yet-to-be-invented tech might save the day. Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

While the original footage in this video was broadcast on 7 News, Labor MP Patrick Gorman (and likely his social media team) added the theme music to TV show Curb Your Enthusiasm, equating the Australian Prime Minister with the fictional version of Larry David, whose ignorance and disregard for social conventions results in awkward, cringe-worthy moments on the show. The addition of end cards further establishes the sitcom style, featuring the names of other coalition members, suggesting that the government’s climate policy is a joke that’s resulted in this bumbling Larry David-like instance of international embarrassment.
description_for_label: PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. Not only did the French president label him a liar over the submarine fiasco, his 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised around the world (and at home) for lacking any new funding, policies or details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day. Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

results.title: Sci-five
results.creator_credit: Roger Seccombe, Russell Porter, Nicholas Alexander and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Sci-five is a film about five very different young Australians who share an absorbing curiousity about the world. It contains interviews with Darren Kelly, Geraldine Milroy, Robert Sinclair, Lindy Coulson and Tim Allen. Each of the five has been a finalist in the BHP Science Prize and their projects provide a focus around which we explore their lives in more detail. The film aims to disprove the common assumption that science is “too hard and too boring” an option for young people. It has no objective commentary, using instead the insights of the teenage scientists themselves. A mosaic structure juxtaposes and intercuts their stories to create a rfascinating documentation of ideas and motives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Seccombe, Russell Porter, Nicholas Alexander and CSIRO

results.title: Scotland: the grand tour
results.creator_credit: Alex Riva, Lawrence Riva and Scotia International Television
results.brief_description: Join John Shedden as he narrates a journey around the sights of Scotland. Included on the stop over are: homes of literary figures Robert Burns and Sir Walter Scott, the River Tweed and the popular activities that she offers, St Andrews Golf Course, University of Saint Andrews, the oldest Norman church in Scotland, Earls Hall, Glamis and Blair Castles, battle sights, the Highland Games, Lang Brothers distillery, pubs, Loch Ness, The Trossachs, Pitlochry, Edinburgh, Loch Lomond, Glencoe, Culloden and many more enticements to potential visitors of this lovely country.

results.title: Scientific advancement
results.creator_credit: James Blake Cahoon and Information Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes the progress made in the production of atomic electric power. Historically interesting for the 1956 prediction that atomic power will be used to eliminate poverty and war.

results.title: Atomic power and the U.S.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
This film examines the United States’ nuclear energy programme for the production of electric power; five types of nuclear reactors designed by U.S. Government laboratories and American industries; nuclear plants operated and financed by private industry. Atomic fuel and technical skills developed by intensive research in the United States are available to other countries through international agreement. No other credits available.

results.title: Training men for the atomic age
results.creator_credit: Hearst Metrotone and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Atoms for Peace”
The training program in nuclear physics for foreign scientists sponsored by the US Atomic Energy Commission. Shows activities at the University of Pennsylvania, Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, International School of Nuclear Science and Engineering at La Grange, Illinois, and construction of a nuclear reactor at Shippingport, Pennsylvania.
